Award.AwardTitle: The 2019 International Conference on Language Documentation & Conservation: Connecting Languages, Communities, and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With more than half of the world's 7000 languages currently at risk of disappearing -- at least 170 of them in the United States alone -- there is an urgent need both to create an enduring documentary record of endangered languages and to support teaching and learning of those languages. Technology offers great promise to accelerate both the documentation and revitalization of endangered languages, since tools developed for major languages can in theory be repurposed to support small, endangered languages. However, this promise of technology has yet to yield significant results. Linguists continue to use ad-hoc and antiquated tools, some developed in the 1980's. Apps for language learning are popular but too often have no grounding in research on language acquisition. Additionally, software development proceeds in a top-down fashion, with little input from stakeholders. To address this disconnect, this project will open a dialogue between linguists, language community members, and software developers to forge robust and reliable solutions for supporting language documentation and conservation. This will be done through a series of targeted workshops and roundtable discussions devoted to bringing stakeholders together around various aspects of language technology. The conference will also feature an Exhibitor Fair with the express purpose of connecting language communities to interested software developers, leading to new collaborations and new science that closely aligns with community goals. Broader impacts include the potential to develop new technology tools and language infrastructure for use by both citizen scientists and linguists; the fostering of relationships with industry through the Exhibitor Fair; and the public online availability of the conference presentations. In addition, conference attendees typically include a large number of citizen scientists from historically underrepresented groups in the sciences, such as Native Americans, Native Alaskans, Native Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, offering opportunities for broadening participation in the language sciences as another broader impact.

This project will bring together leading scholars from across the world to explore connections between language and technology as part of the 2019 International Conference on Language Documentation and Conservation (ICLDC), hosted by the University of Hawai'i at Manoa. Since its inception in 2009, ICLDC has become the flagship venue driving scholarship in the documentation, maintenance and revitalization of endangered languages. Participants include undergraduate students, graduate students and faculty from linguistics, anthropology, biology, computer science, and other academic disciplines. ICLDC offers its highly diverse audience opportunities for informal science education and training that includes new methodologies and best practices in cutting edge language documentation and that crosses traditional disciplinary boundaries. A recognized need among linguists is to better integrate and extend these tools as well as develop new ones for data management, and this conference has the potential to increase digital support for the language sciences, for archiving and for open access more generally. In addition, this conference serves as one of the foremost venues for the dissemination of research findings in language documentation and conservation and related disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 6th International Conference on Language Documentation & Conservation (ICLDC) was held at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa, February 28 -- March 3, 2019. The conference theme "Connecting Communities, Languages and Technology" recognized the vital role that technology has come to play in work with small and endangered languages. The conference thus strove to forge closer links between Indigenous communities and those working in the language technology sphere. 

ICLDC6 was once again very popular, featuring over 200 presentations on over 125 languages, representing peoples and cultures from all over the world. The program committee received a record number of abstracts but was only able to accept just over half of the submissions to space limitations. Participants came from across the United States as well as 30 other countries, reflecting the leading role that the US continues to play in the field of language documentation and conservation. The conference also featured a large number of local participants, with nearly 100 people attending the special Sunday session on Hawaiian language, which featured a Talk Story session conducted entirely in Hawaiian language.

The conference included several unique features made possible through NSF funding:

Two plenary presentations by Indigenous Pacific Islanders: 

  • Te Taka Keegan (University of Waikato) Language Normalisation through Technology: Te Reo Māori Example

  • Kau?i Sai-Dudoit (Awaiaulu) Nānā I Ke Kumu: Look to the source

Six special workshops focused on hands-on training in particular language technologies: 

  • Rapid Word Collection workshops: Why & how to do them (Brenda Boerger and Jermiah Avial)

  • Introduction to Mukurtu CMS: Connecting and Sharing Cultural Collections and Language Materials (Kimberly Christen, Michael Wynne and Alana Pollack)

  • Bloom: Now communities can create their own books (John Hatton)

  • Accelerating the analysis of your audio recordings with untrained forced speech alignment (Rolando Coto-Solano, Sally Akevai (Ake), Nicholas, Samantha Wray and Tyler Peterson)

  • Transcription acceleration for language documentation with ELPIS (Ben Foley, Daan van Esch and Nay San)

  • How to make a Mother Tongues' digital dictionary (Mark Turin and Aidan Pine) 

Six "Talk Story" sessions fostering small-group discussion around issues of communities and language technology: 

  • Connecting technology and language revitalization from a community-based perspective (Britt Dunlop, Jacqueline Jim, and Kyra Fortier)

  • Decolonizing Indigenous Language Technologies: Centering Communities and Their Languages in Technology (Wesley Leonard, Megan Lukaniec, and Adrienne Tsikewa)

  • Talking about child language documentation: Experiences, barriers, methods & outcomes (Barbara Kelly)

  • I ?ike ?ia ke kanaka ma kāna ?ōlelo: ka wehewehe ?ana i nā mana?o like ?ole e pili ana no ka ?ōlelo (Hawai?i Ideologies about Hawaiian Language Revitalization and Reclamation) (Katie Drager, Haʻalilio Solomon, and Hina Puamohala Kneubuhl) [Presented once in English and once entirely in Hawaiian)

  • Leveraging technology to recirculate songs in endangered languages (Clint Bracknell, Linda Barwick, Linda Payi Ford, Emily Ford and Chloe Ford)

  • Immersing Our Homes and Relationships: A discussion of the successes and struggles of heritage language transmission (Whitney Nephew, Kawennii'stha Nicole Martin, and Yeya't'n:nis Alexis Martin)

The conference was held in conjunction with two complementary programs. The 3rd ComputEL conference, dedicated to supporting technology for indigenous and endangered languages, was held immediately prior to the ICLDC. The Hilo Field Study, in which participants visit the Hawaiian immersion K-12 and University programs on the Big Island of Hawaii was held in the two days following ICLDC. 

Recordings of all the talks, as well as any slides, papers, handouts or posters associated with the presentations and the Workshops at the ICLDC have been deposited in ScholarSpace, the UH Manoa institutional repository. They are freely downloadable at https://hdl.handle.net/10125/62932.
